title: 108_hr1079
content: The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" may be cited as the Act. It includes increased expensing for small businesses. The "Neutral Cost Recovery Act for Small Business" increases the expensing limit to $75,000 and the phaseout threshold to $325,000 under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also includes certain computer software as eligible section 179 property. The definition of section 179 property under the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include tangible property, computer software, and section 1245 property acquired for business use. The term excludes certain properties and air conditioning/heating units. Additionally, an inflation adjustment provision is added to the dollar limitation and phaseout threshold. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include various types of property for business use under section 179, excluding specific items like air conditioning/heating units. An inflation adjustment provision is also added to the dollar limitation and phaseout threshold. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include various types of property for business use under section 179, excluding specific items like air conditioning/heating units. An inflation adjustment provision is added to the dollar limitation and phaseout threshold, allowing rounding to the nearest multiple of $1,000 and $10,000 respectively. Additionally, the revocation of election under paragraph (1) of section 179(c) is permitted for taxpayers. The taxpayer may revoke an election under paragraph (1) of section 179(c) of the Internal Revenue Code, with the revocation being irrevocable once made. These amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. Neutral cost recovery depreciation adjustment for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. Section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for a deduction adjustment to mimic expensing for certain property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The deduction amount is modified to 150 percent instead of 200 percent for eligible property, with specific conditions for taxable years following the year the property is placed in service. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for eligible property placed in service after December 31, 2003, is determined by multiplying the deduction amount under Section 168 without adjustments by the gross domestic product deflator for the corresponding calendar quarter. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio for eligible property is determined by dividing the GDP deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the GDP deflator for the same quarter, then multiplying by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The applicable neutral cost recovery ratio is calculated by dividing the GDP deflator for the quarter when the property was placed in service by the GDP deflator for the same quarter, then multiplying by 1.035 to the power of the number of full years since the property was placed in service. The ratio is rounded to the nearest \1/1000\ and shall never be less than 1. The neutral cost recovery ratio is determined without considering certain subparagraphs. The GDP deflator for a quarter is used to calculate the ratio, and taxpayers can elect not to apply this subsection to their property. Churning transactions and additional deductions do not affect the property's basis or recapture. The additional deduction under subsection (f)(5)(A)(ii) does not impact the adjusted basis of property or interests in pass-thru entities. Pass-thru entities include regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. The minimum tax treatment for certain entities includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates, trusts, and common trust funds. The deduction allowable for property under section 168(k) after December 31, 2003, is calculated using a neutral cost recovery ratio. The deduction allowable for property under section 168(k) is calculated using a neutral cost recovery ratio. This applies to taxable years when the property is placed in service, with exceptions for certain elections and coordination with depreciation limitations on automobiles. The deduction under section 168(k) is not applicable to the additional deduction for passenger automobiles. The amendments apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2003.
